stream_context.summary: Kaze began by debugging a crash and reviewing performance metrics before dedicating the majority of the stream to the art and level design of Course 14, the craft-themed level. He brainstormed and prototyped solutions for the level's background and death-plane, experimenting with textures and implementing a custom 'shiny paint' visual effect. He also discussed future YouTube content ideas and the project's overall progress with his viewers.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing the end of its course design phase, with work focused on Course 14 of 15. Course 15 is conceptually complete, but the overworld, side levels, and final boss level still need to be created.
A major design challenge in the craft level (Course 14) is creating a death plane that fits the diorama theme but is unambiguously a hazard, leading Kaze to reject ideas like a desk or carpet.
development_findings.quote: The problem with the desk is that people might think they can walk on it and we don't want the player to think they can walk on it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze references cloud designs from another of his projects, 'Peach's Fury,' as a potential starting point for the craft level's aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I think what we have in Peach's Fury is good.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom, low-cost visual effect to simulate shiny paint on the N64 by creating a 'fake normal map' that changes brightness based on the camera's angle relative to the surface.
development_findings.quote: Shall I add a fake normal map to this? So that when you turn the camera, there's like highlights like this moving... This should be a pretty cheap effect that looks really good.

development_findings.summary: Kaze notes that the cardboard level will be very difficult to optimize for N64 hardware due to its open nature, anticipating future performance challenges.

Kaze has discovered that after significant optimization, the N64's true performance bottleneck is the RSP (Reality Signal Processor), not memory bandwidth, a topic he wants to make a video on but feels he needs more expertise in.
development_findings.quote: The RSP is the bottleneck. I'm not entirely comfortable making this video yet, because there's so much RSP stuff I don't understand yet.

development_findings.summary: To solve the 'diorama' framing problem, Kaze decides to enclose the entire level in a distant, non-collidable 3D room, making it appear as if the player is in a house looking at the craft project.
Kaze experienced a game crash caused by an overflow in the number of collision nodes generated, which happened when he was placing a large number of mountain assets.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distinguishes between his YouTube content creation, which he views as a job, and the game development itself, which he considers the fun part.
context_findings.quote: For me, YouTube at this point is the job part and like making the game is the fun part.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games like Paper Mario: The Origami King fail when they lack extrinsic motivation, indicating his design philosophy values tangible reward systems over purely intrinsic gameplay.
context_findings.quote: The entire game just exists for you to play it for the sake of playing it. And it failed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze consciously avoids using assets from the Nintendo "Giga Leak" out of fear of severe repercussions from Nintendo, who he feels is already targeting his channel.
context_findings.quote: I on purpose stayed away from the giga league as much as I could because I figured if I ever look at the giga league and do content with it they're gonna completely murder me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to making the game a pure 3D platformer, explicitly rejecting the inclusion of 2D sections similar to those in Super Mario Odyssey.
context_findings.quote: I want this to be a 3D game entirely.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses a long list of potential YouTube video ideas with his audience, revealing his content strategy and his awareness of what performs well on the platform, such as 30-minute videos.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently working on a complete remake of Course 1, and the completion of this task is a prerequisite for releasing the game's public demo.
Biobak provided the core concept for the background of Course 14, suggesting a paper cylinder with drawings on it to create the diorama aesthetic.
biobak.quote: Biobak was suggesting that there would be like... That this whole thing would be inside a paper cylinder. And the paper cylinder is gonna have stuff drawn onto it.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina (referred to as 'Eiza') collaborated on a slide deck to plan out Course 15, indicating a structured, conceptual pre-production process they share.
zeina.quote: Course 15 is also already halfway done because I already programmed all the assets for it, for the slide deck I made with Eiza.

key_stories.title: The Diorama's Edge
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to design a death floor for the craft level that fit the diorama aesthetic without being misleading. After rejecting several ideas, he settled on a solution combining a wrapping paper floor, a painted paper cylinder background, and an outer room to frame the scene, effectively solving the core thematic and gameplay challenge.
key_stories.challenge: The craft-themed level (Course 14) needed a background and a bottomless pit that felt like a diorama without confusing the player into thinking a floor or desk was a safe, playable area.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed numerous ideas with his chat, rejecting concepts like a desk, carpet, and lava. He prototyped textures for the floor, including aluminum foil and finally wrapping paper. He implemented Biobak's suggestion for a paper cylinder background and added details like a visible seam with tape to enhance the crafted feel.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a multi-part solution: a wrapping paper texture for the 'water' floor, a painted paper cylinder for the walls (an idea from Biobak), and enclosing the entire scene in a distant 3D room to create the illusion of looking at a diorama on a table without actually showing the table.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem with the desk is that people might think they can walk on it and we don't want the player to think they can walk on it.

key_stories.title: Faking Shininess on the N64
key_stories.summary: To make a painted surface look shiny on the N64, Kaze designed and implemented a custom, low-performance-cost 'fake normal map' effect. This creative workaround uses the camera's angle to simulate light reflection, demonstrating how he innovates within hardware constraints to achieve a specific artistic vision.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to make the painted background of the craft level look shiny, as if it were wet paint, but lacked the hardware capabilities for modern shaders like normal maps on the N64.
key_stories.process: Kaze devised the idea of a 'fake normal map' and wrote code for the N64's combiner to create the effect. He rejected more performance-heavy modern techniques like shell texturing. He then debugged and tweaked the parameters of his effect live on stream until it was visible and achieved the subtle, shiny look he envisioned.
key_stories.outcome: He successfully created a simple, low-cost shader effect that simulates a specular highlight, making the paint appear shiny. The effect works by brightening the texture based on the camera's viewing angle, achieving the desired aesthetic within the strict limitations of the N64.
key_stories.key_quote: Shall I add a fake normal map to this? So that when you turn the camera, there's like highlights like this moving. Oh, that would look so good.
